TopicTitle: So today in class, I showed my classmates and my science teacher KSP.

Articles.Content:
While presenting on rocket science on a projector, my teacher wanted a demostration on my powerpoint. Fortunately, I had KSP on the laptop so I decided to show them KSP. Let me tell ya, the first thing they payed attentioned to was the kerbals (unfortunately no bill jeb or bob), they were SCARED. Anyways when I launched my makeshift rocket to orbit, they were already telling me to

-crash it

-turn it

-do a barrel roll

Right as I was cruising to apoapsis, the period ended unfortunately. Fortunately, my teacher let me continue on another day. I just wish that Bill Jeb and Bob was there on my trip
Pretty cool. Matter of time before a someone who played with KSP as a kid becomes an actual astronaut.

Next year we study Spacecraft design.

I'm desperately trying to find out who teaches it so I can make them use KSP in a lecture XD
I have wanted to do this for a while. How exactly did you manage to convince your teacher to let you do this?

I have wanted to do this for a while. How exactly did you manage to convince your teacher to let you do this?

Most likely a modern thinking instructor. An applied visual aid is the best means to teach and learn. If the teacher is familar with KSP and how it works, it is an ideal tool for helping people understand the concepts and physics of space, which then can be extrapolated on with the theory.

I've been hassling my students with my KSP misadventures all year long! I had a couple roll there eyes as I was explaining how I used a couple of equations to place a multi-satellite platform into a 4:5 orbital insertion so I could get even coverage for my GPS system. A couple of them did a demo for Newton's Second Law and projectile motion for their final projects. I will probably be setting up a KSP page on my school site for the summer break.
